original: Sūtra / vṛkṣa I Baum
analyzed: sūtra vṛkṣa i baum
translated: Sutra. A tree, etc.

original: NidSa / śrāvastyāṃ nidānam /
analyzed: śrāvastyām nidānam
translated: NidSa. With Shravasti as the starting point.

original: NidSa / tatra bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayati /
analyzed: tatra bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayati
translated: NidSa. There the Blessed One addressed the monks:

original: NidSa / upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv āsvādānudarśino viharatas tṛṣṇā pravardhate /
analyzed: upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu āsvāda anudarśinaḥ viharataḥ tṛṣṇā pravardhate
translated: NidSa. For one who dwells observing enjoyment in things that can lead to attachment, craving increases.

original: tṛṣṇāpratyayam upādānam /🔽upādānapratyayo bhavaḥ /
analyzed: tṛṣṇā pratyayam upādānam  upādāna pratyayaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: Craving is a condition for attachment.🔽Attachment is a condition for becoming.

original: bhavapratyayā jātiḥ /
analyzed: bhava pratyayā jātiḥ
translated: Becoming is a condition for birth.

original: jātipratyayaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: jāti pratyayam jarā maraṇam śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: With birth as a condition, aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come into being.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo samudayo bhavati /🔽NidSa / tadyathā vṛkṣasya navasya daharasya puruṣa utpadyeta arthakāmo hitakāmo
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya samudayaḥ samudayaḥ bhavati  tat yathā vṛkṣasya navasya daharasya puruṣaḥ utpadyeta artha kāmaḥ hita kāmaḥ
translated: Thus there is an origination of this whole mass of suffering.🔽NidSa. Just as if a man, desiring welfare, desiring benefit,

original: yogakṣemakāmo yas taṃ vṛkṣaṃ kālena kālam
analyzed: yogakṣema kāmaḥ yaḥ tam vṛkṣam
translated: desiring peace, desiring ease, were to plant a new tree, and from time to time

original: utkīlayet kālena kālaṃ śītoṣṇa kālena kālam udakaṃ dadyāt /
analyzed: utkīlayet kālena kālam śīta uṣṇa          kālena kālam udakam dadyāt
translated: he would dig around its roots, water it, and protect it from cold and heat,

original: sa vṛkṣas tannidānaṃ vṛddhiṃ virūḍhim vipulatām āpadyeta /
analyzed: sa vṛkṣaḥ tad nidānam vṛddhim virūḍhim vipula tām āpadyeta
translated: that tree, for that reason, would grow, develop, and expand.

original: NidSa / evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv āsvādānudarśino viharatas tṛṣṇā pravardhate pūrvavad yāvat samudayo bhavati /
analyzed: evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu āsvāda anudarśinaḥ viharataḥ tṛṣṇā pravardhate pūrvavat yāvat samudayaḥ bhavati
translated: NidSa: Just so, when one dwells observing gratification in things that can be clung to, craving increases, as before, up to: there is an origination of this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargānudarśinas tṛṣṇā nirudhyate /
analyzed: upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga anudarśinaḥ tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
translated: NidSa: When one dwells observing impermanence in things that can be clung to, observing non-self, observing detachment, observing cessation, observing relinquishment in things that can be clung to, craving ceases.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ/🔽upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhāh /
analyzed: upādāna nirodhāt bhava nirodhāt
translated: With the cessation of craving, clinging ceases.🔽With the cessation of clinging, existence ceases.

original: bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /🔽jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ  jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of existence, birth ceases.

original: śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsā nirudhyante /
analyzed: śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyante
translated: With the cessation of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish cease.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya nirodho bhavati /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus ceases this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / tadyathā tasyaiva vṛkṣasya navasya daharasya / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / /
analyzed: tat yathā tasya eva vṛkṣasya navasya daharasya
translated: NidSa: Just as, for that very tree, young, tender, soft, and pliant...

original: puruṣa utpadyeta anarthakāmo 'hitakāmo 'yogakṣemakāmo yas taṃ
analyzed: utpadyeta
translated: a person might appear who desires harm, desires injury, desires lack of well-being, who

analyzed: vṛkṣam mūlāt śitvā
translated: Having cut down the tree at the root, the top...

original: vātātapābhyāṃ pariśoṣayet /🔽vātātapābhyāṃ pariśoṣayitvā agninā dahet /
analyzed: pariśoṣayet  vāta ātapābhyām pariśoṣayitvā agninā dahet
translated: ... would be dried up by wind and sun.🔽Having dried it up by wind and sun, it would be burned by fire.

analyzed: agninā dagdhvā
translated: Having been burned by fire, it would be reduced to ashes.

original: NidSa / kiṃ manyadhve bhikṣavo nanu sa vṛkṣas tan nidānam ucchinnamūlas tālamastakavad anābhavagatika āyatyām anutpādadharmā /
analyzed: kim manyadhve bhikṣavaḥ nanu sa vṛkṣaḥ tat nidānam ucchinna mūlaḥ tāla mastaka vat an ābhava gatikaḥ āyatyām an utpāda dharmā
translated: What do you think, monks? Would that tree, with its root cut off, like the top of a palm tree, be destroyed, gone to its end, reduced to ashes,

original: NidSa / evaṃ bhadanta /
analyzed: evam bhadanta
translated: Yes, Venerable One.

original: NidSa / evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargānudarśinas tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
analyzed: evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga anudarśinaḥ tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
translated: Just so, monks, when one sees the impermanence of the appropriated phenomena, sees their destruction, sees their disappearance, sees their letting go, craving ceases.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /🔽upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /
translated: When craving ceases, clinging ceases.🔽When clinging ceases, existence ceases.

original: bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /🔽jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ  jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: When existence ceases, birth ceases.

original: śokaparidevaduḥkhaurmanasyopāyāsā nirudhyante /
analyzed: śoka parideva duḥkha aurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyante
translated: When birth ceases, old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair cease.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya niodho bhavati /🔽NidSa / atha te bhikṣavo bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya niodhaḥ bhavati  atha te bhikṣavaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhyanandan
translated: Thus there is the cessation of this entire great mass of suffering.🔽Then those monks rejoiced in the words of the Blessed One.

original: abhinandyānumodya bhagavato 'ntikāt prakrāntāḥ //
analyzed: abhinandya anumodya bhagavataḥ ntikāt prakrāntāḥ
translated: Having rejoiced and approved, they departed from the presence of the Blessed One.

original: Sūtra / vṛkṣa II Baum
analyzed: sūtra vṛkṣa ii baum
translated: Sutra. Tree II

original: NidSa / śrāvastyāṃ nidānam /
analyzed: śrāvastyām nidānam
translated: NidSa. The setting is in Shravasti.

original: NidSa / tatra bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayati /
analyzed: tatra bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayati
translated: NidSa. There the Blessed One addressed the monks:

original: NidSa / upādānīyeṣu bhikṣavo dharmeṣv āsvānudarṣino viharato hārakaṃ vijñānaṃ bhavati nāmarūpe /
analyzed: upādānīyeṣu bhikṣavaḥ dharmeṣu āsvānudarṣinaḥ viharataḥ hārakam vijñānam bhavati nāma rūpe
translated: NidSa. Monks, when one dwells not penetrating the things that can be clung to as such, consciousness comes to be with name-and-form as condition.

original: nāma rūpapratyayaṃ ṣaḍāyatam /
analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam ṣaṣ āyatam
translated: With name-and-form as condition: the six sense bases.

original: ṣaḍāyatanapratyayaḥ sparśaḥ /🔽sparśapratyayā vedanā /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana pratyayaḥ sparśaḥ  sparśa pratyayā vedanā
translated: With the six sense bases as condition: contact.🔽With contact as condition: feeling.

original: vedanāpratyayātṛṣṇā /🔽tṛṣṇāpratyayam upādānam /
analyzed: vedanā pratyayā atṛṣṇā  tṛṣṇā pratyayam upādānam
translated: With feeling as condition: craving.🔽With craving as condition: clinging.

original: upādānapratyayo bhavaḥ /
analyzed: upādāna pratyayaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: With clinging as condition: existence.

original: bhavapratyayā jātiḥ /
analyzed: bhava pratyayā jātiḥ
translated: With existence as condition: birth.

original: jātipratyayaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: jāti pratyayam jarā maraṇam śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: With birth as condition: old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair (all) arise.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavati /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya samudayaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus there is an origination of this whole mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / tadyathā mahāvṛkṣasya mulāvataḥ skandhavataḥ sāravataḥ śākhāpattraphalopetasya yāni cādhogatāni mūlāni tāny tāny ūrdhvam ojam abhiharanti
analyzed: tat yathā mahā vṛkṣasya mulāvataḥ skandhavataḥ sāravataḥ śākhā pattra phala upetasya yāni ca adhas gatāni mūlāni tāni tāni ūrdhvam ojam abhiharanti
translated: NidSa 1.1.1. It is just as with a great tree that has roots, a trunk, a core, and is endowed with branches, leaves, and fruit. The roots that go down take up the sap and

original: evaṃ hi sa mahāvṛkṣas tadāhāras tadupādāno dīrgham adhvānaṃ tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: evam hi sa mahā vṛkṣaḥ tad āhāraḥ tad upādānaḥ dīrgham adhvānam tiṣṭhati
translated: thus that great tree, nourished by that, stands for a long time.

original: NidSa / evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv āsvādānudarśino viharato hārakaṃ vijñānaṃ bhavati nāmarūpe /
analyzed: evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu āsvāda anudarśinaḥ viharataḥ hārakam vijñānam bhavati nāma rūpe
translated: NidSa 1.1.2. In the same way, when one dwells contemplating enjoyment in things that can be clung to, consciousness is nourished by name-and-form.

original: pūrvavad yāyad evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavati /
analyzed: pūrvavat yāyat evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya samudayaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus there is an origin for this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargarśino na hārakaṃ vijñānaṃ bhavati nāmarupe /
analyzed: upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga rśinaḥ na hārakam vijñānam bhavati nāma rupe
translated: NidSa 1.1.3. But when one dwells contemplating impermanence in things that can be clung to, contemplating non-self, contemplating dispassion, contemplating cessation, and contemplating letting go, consciousness is not nourished by name-and-form.

original: tasya nirodhāt ṣaḍāyatananirodhaḥ /
analyzed: tasya nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: From its cessation, the cessation of the six sense spheres.

original: ṣaḍāyatananirodhāt sparśanirodaḥ /🔽sparśanirodhād vedanānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhāt sparśa nirodaḥ  sparśa nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of the six sense spheres, the cessation of contact.🔽From the cessation of contact, the cessation of feeling.

original: vedanānirodhāt tṛṣṇānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: vedanā nirodhāt tṛṣṇā nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of feeling, the cessation of craving.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /🔽upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /🔽bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of craving, the cessation of clinging.🔽From the cessation of clinging, the cessation of existence.🔽From the cessation of existence, the cessation of birth.

original: jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of birth, the cessation of old age and death.

original: śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsā nirudhyante /
analyzed: śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyante
translated: Sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya nirodho bhavati /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus ceases this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / tadyathā tasyaiva mahāvṛkṣasya mūlavataḥ skandhavataḥ sāravataḥ śākhāpattraphalopetasya puruṣa utpadyeta / / / / / / / / / / / / /
analyzed: tat yathā tasya eva mahā vṛkṣasya mūlavataḥ skandhavataḥ sāravataḥ śākhā pattra phala upetasya puruṣaḥ utpadyeta
translated: Just as, monks, for that very great tree with roots, trunk, heartwood, branches, leaves, and fruit, a man would arise...

original: NidSa / kiṃ manyadhve bhikṣavo nanu sa mahāvṛkṣas tannidānam ucchinnamūlas tālamastakavad anābhavagatika āyatyām anutpādadharmā /
analyzed: kim manyadhve bhikṣavaḥ nanu sa mahā vṛkṣaḥ tad nidānam ucchinna mūlaḥ tāla mastaka vat an ābhava gatikaḥ āyatyām an utpāda dharmā
translated: What do you think, monks? Would that great tree, with that as its root cause, be cut off at the root, like a palm tree, unable to grow again in the future?

original: NidSa / evaṃ bhadanta /
analyzed: evam bhadanta
translated: Yes, Venerable.

original: NidSa / evaṃ eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargānudarśino na hārakaṃ vijñānaṃ bhavati nāmarūpe /
analyzed: evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga anudarśinaḥ na hārakam vijñānam bhavati nāma rūpe
translated: So it is, monks. In the same way, for those who see conditioned things as impermanent, as subject to destruction, as subject to cessation, as subject to giving up, consciousness does not descend into name-and-form.

original: tasya nirodhāt ṣaḍāyatananirodhāḥ /
analyzed: tasya nirodhāt ṣaṭ āyatana nirodhāḥ
translated: From the cessation of that, the cessation of the six sense bases.

original: pūrvavad yāvan nirodho bhavati /🔽NidSa / atha te bhikṣavo bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan /
analyzed: pūrvavat yāvat nirodhaḥ bhavati  atha te bhikṣavaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhyanandan
translated: As before, up to cessation occurs.🔽The monks rejoiced in the Blessed One's words.

original: abhinandyānumodya bhagavato 'ntikāt prakrāntāḥ //
analyzed: abhinandya anumodya bhagavataḥ ntikāt prakrāntāḥ
translated: Having rejoiced and delighted in the Blessed One's words, they departed from the Blessed One's presence.

original: Sūtra und / dīpa I und II Lampe
analyzed: sūtra und dīpa i und ii lampe
translated: Sutra and Dīpa I and II Lamps

original: NidSa / pūrvaṃ me bhikṣavo 'nuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhim anabhisaṃbuddhasyaikākino rahasigatasyaivaṃ cetasi cetaḥparivitarka udapādi /
analyzed: pūrvam me bhikṣavaḥ nuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim an abhisaṃbuddhasya ekākinaḥ rahasi gatasya evam cetasi cetaḥ parivitarkaḥ udapādi
translated: NidSa. Monks, before I fully awakened to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, while I was still an unawakened Bodhisattva, living alone in seclusion, this mental reflection arose in my mind:

original: NidSa / kṛcchraṃ batāyaṃ loka āpanno yad uta jāyate 'pi jīryate 'pi mriyate 'pi cyavate 'py upapadyate 'pi /
analyzed: kṛcchram bata ayam lokaḥ āpannaḥ yat uta jāyate pi jīryate pi mriyate pi cyavate pi upapadyate pi
translated: Alas, this world has fallen into a difficult situation, in that it is born, ages, dies, falls, and is reborn.

original: atha ca punar ime satvā jarāmaraṇasyottare niḥsaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ na prajānanti /
analyzed: atha ca punar ime satvāḥ jarā maraṇasya uttare niḥsaraṇam yathābhūtam na prajānanti
translated: And yet, these beings do not truly understand the way to go beyond old age and death.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati jarāmaraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati jarā maraṇam bhavati
translated: NidSa. This occurred to me:🔽When what exists does old age and death occur?

original: kiṃpratyayañ ca punar jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayam ca punar jarā maraṇam
translated: And with what as condition does old age and death occur?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: As I investigated this properly with wisdom, this was the breakthrough knowledge that arose in me:

original: jātyāṃ satyāṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: jātyām satyām jarā maraṇam bhavati
translated: When there is birth, there is old age and death.

original: jātipratyayañ ca punar jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: jāti pratyayam ca punar jarā maraṇam
translated: And birth is a condition for old age and death.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati jātir bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati jātiḥ bhavati
translated: I thought:🔽When what exists does birth come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayā ca punar jātiḥ /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayā ca punar jātiḥ
translated: With what as its requisite condition is there birth?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: As I remained focused in this way, there arose in me knowledge of the past, with insight and vision.

original: bhave sati jātir bhavati /
analyzed: bhave sati jātiḥ bhavati
translated: When there is existence, birth comes to be.

original: bhavapratyayā ca punar jātiḥ /
analyzed: bhava pratyayā ca punar jātiḥ
translated: And existence is a requisite condition for birth.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati bhavo bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati bhavaḥ bhavati
translated: I thought:🔽When what exists does existence come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayaś ca punar bhavaḥ /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayaḥ ca punar bhavaḥ
translated: With what as its requisite condition is there existence?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: As I remained focused in this way, there arose in me knowledge of the past, with insight and vision.

original: upādāne sati bhavo bhavati /
analyzed: upādāne sati bhavaḥ bhavati
translated: When there is clinging, existence comes to be.

original: upādānapratyayaś ca punar bhavaḥ /
analyzed: upādāna pratyayaḥ ca punar bhavaḥ
translated: And clinging is a requisite condition for existence.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu saty upādānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati upādānam bhavati
translated: I thought:🔽When what exists does clinging come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayañ ca punar upādānam /

original: bhavapratyayā jātiḥ /

translated: Becoming is a condition for birth.

translated: So it is, monks. For one who dwells observing enjoyment in things that can be clung to, craving increases. Craving is a condition for clinging.

translated: With the cessation of birth, aging and death cease.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /

original: kasya nirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /

translated: With the cessation of what does birth cease?🔽While reflecting carefully, this appeared to me:

translated: When what does not exist does existence not exist?

original: kasya nirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt bhava nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does existence cease?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /

original: upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: It occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asaty upādānaṃ na bhavati /

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: When I was attending carefully, this is how I came to understand the truth of this:

original: upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargānudarśinas tṛṣṇā nirudhyate /
analyzed: upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga anudarśinaḥ tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
translated: When one sees the impermanence of things that can be clung to, sees their disappearance, sees their falling apart, sees their unattractiveness, sees cessation, sees relinquishment, craving ceases.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /🔽upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /🔽bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of craving, there is the cessation of clinging.🔽From the cessation of clinging, there is the cessation of existence.🔽From the cessation of existence, there is the cessation of birth.

original: jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of birth, there is the cessation of old age and death.

original: śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsā nirudhyante /
analyzed: śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyante
translated: Sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya nirodho bhavati /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus there is the cessation of this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / kiṃ manyadhve bhikṣavaḥ / / / /

translated: What do you think, monks?

original: NidSa / evaṃ bhadanata /
analyzed: evam bhadanata
translated: “Just so, Bhadanta.”

original: NidSa / evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargānudarśinas tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
analyzed: evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga anudarśinaḥ tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
translated: “In the same way, when one sees the impermanence of things that can be clung to, sees their disappearance, sees their falling apart, sees their unattractiveness, sees cessation, sees relinquishment, craving ceases.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /
translated: From the cessation of craving, the cessation of clinging.

original: pūrvavad yāvan nirodho bhavati /🔽NidSa / atha te bhikṣavo bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan /

translated: As before, up to the cessation of suffering occurs.🔽The monks rejoiced in the Blessed One's words.

original: abhinandyānumodya bhagavato 'ntikāt prakrāntāḥ //
analyzed: abhinandya anumodya bhagavataḥ ntikāt prakrāntāḥ
translated: After rejoicing and approving, they rose from their seats and departed from the Blessed One's presence.

original: Sūtra
analyzed: sūtra
translated: Sutra

original: NidSa / pūrvaṃ me bhikṣavo 'nuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhim anabhisaṃbuddhasyaikākino rahasigatasyaivaṃ cetasi cetaḥparivitarka udapādi /
analyzed: pūrvam me bhikṣavaḥ nuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim an abhisaṃbuddhasya ekākinaḥ rahasi gatasya evam cetasi cetaḥ parivitarkaḥ udapādi
translated: NidSa. Monks, before I fully awakened to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, while I was still an unawakened Bodhisattva, living alone in seclusion, this train of thought arose in my mind:

original: NidSa / kṛcchraṃ batāyaṃ loka āpanno yad uta jāyate 'pi jīryate 'pi mriyate 'pi cyavate 'py upapadyate 'pi /
analyzed: kṛcchram bata ayam lokaḥ āpannaḥ yat uta jāyate pi jīryate pi mriyate pi cyavate pi upapadyate pi
translated: Alas, this world has fallen into trouble, in that it is born, ages, dies, transmigrates, and is reborn.

original: atha ca punar ime satvā jarāmaraṇasyottare niḥsaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ na prajānanti /
analyzed: atha ca punar ime satvāḥ jarā maraṇasya uttare niḥsaraṇam yathābhūtam na prajānanti
translated: And yet, these beings do not truly understand the way to go beyond aging and death.

analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati jarā maraṇam bhavati
translated: Then this occurred to me:🔽When what exists does aging and death occur?

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /🔽upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /🔽bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of craving, there is the cessation of clinging.🔽From the cessation of clinging, there is the cessation of existence.🔽From the cessation of existence, there is the cessation of birth.

original: jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of birth, there is the cessation of old age and death.

original: śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsā nirudhyante /
analyzed: śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyante
translated: Sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya nirodho bhavati /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus there is the cessation of this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / kiṃ manyadhve bhikṣavaḥ / / / /
analyzed: nidsa kim manyadhve bhikṣavaḥ
translated: What do you think, monks?

original: NidSa / evaṃ bhadanata /
analyzed: evam bhadanata
translated: “Yes, Venerable Sir,” they replied.

original: NidSa / evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣv anityānudarśino vibhavānudarśino virāgānudarśino nirodhānudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsargānudarśinas tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
analyzed: evam eva upādānīyeṣu dharmeṣu anitya anudarśinaḥ vibhava anudarśinaḥ virāga anudarśinaḥ nirodha anudarśinaḥ pratiniḥsarga anudarśinaḥ tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
translated: “Monks, it is just so. When one sees the impermanence of things that can be clung to, sees their disappearance, sees their falling apart, sees their unattractiveness, sees cessation, sees relinquishment, craving ceases.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /
translated: From the cessation of craving, the cessation of clinging.

original: pūrvavad yāvan nirodho bhavati /🔽NidSa / atha te bhikṣavo bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan /
analyzed: pūrvavat yāvat nirodhaḥ bhavati  atha te bhikṣavaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhyanandan
translated: As before, up to the cessation of suffering occurs.🔽The monks rejoiced in the Blessed One's words.

original: abhinandyānumodya bhagavato 'ntikāt prakrāntāḥ //
analyzed: abhinandya anumodya bhagavataḥ ntikāt prakrāntāḥ
translated: Having rejoiced and delighted in the Blessed One's words, they departed from his presence.

original: Sūtra / nagarasūtra
analyzed: sūtra nagarasūtra
translated: Sutra. The City Sutra

original: NidSa / siddham /
analyzed: nid sa siddham
translated: The Nidana. It is established.

original: evaṃ mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavāñ śrāvastyāṃ viharati sma jetavane 'nāthapiṇḍadasyārāme /
analyzed: evam mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavām śrāvastyām viharati sma jetavane nāthapiṇḍadasya ārāme
translated: Thus have I heard. At one time the Blessed One was dwelling in Shravasti, in Jeta's Grove, in Anathapindika's park.

original: tatra bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayati /
analyzed: tatra bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayati
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the monks:

original: NidSa / pūrvaṃ me bhikṣavo 'nuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhim anabhisaṃbuddhasyaikākino rahasigatasya pratisaṃlīnasyaivaṃ cetasi cetaḥparivitarka udapādi
analyzed: pūrvam me bhikṣavaḥ nuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim an abhisaṃbuddhasya ekākinaḥ rahasi gatasya pratisaṃlīnasya evam cetasi cetaḥ parivitarkaḥ udapādi
translated: The Nidana. Before I fully awakened to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, while I was still a bodhisattva, alone in seclusion, this thought arose in my mind:

original: NidSa / kṛcchraṃ batāyaṃ loka āpanno yaduta jāyate'pi jīryate 'pi mriyate 'pi cyavate 'py upapadyate 'pi /
analyzed: kṛcchram bata ayam lokaḥ āpannaḥ yat uta jāyate pi jīryate pi mriyate pi cyavate pi upapadyate pi
translated: 'Alas, this world has fallen into a difficult situation, in that it is born, ages, dies, falls, and is reborn.

original: atha ca punar ime sattvā jarāmaraṇasyottare niḥsaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ na prajānanti /
analyzed: atha ca punar ime sattvāḥ jarā maraṇasya uttare niḥsaraṇam yathābhūtam na prajānanti
translated: And yet these beings do not truly understand the escape from old age and death.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: ' Then it occurred to me:

original: kasmin nu sati jarāmaraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu sati jarā maraṇam bhavati
translated: When what exists does old age and death come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayañ ca punar jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayam ca punar jarā maraṇam
translated: And with what as condition is old age and death?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasikurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽jātyāṃ satyāṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasikurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  jātyām satyām jarā maraṇam bhavati
translated: As I pondered this, my friends, the breakthrough came:🔽When there is birth, old age and death come to be.

original: jātipratyayañ ca punar jāramaraṇam /
analyzed: jāti pratyayam ca punar jāra maraṇam
translated: And with birth as condition is old age and death.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati jātir bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati jātiḥ bhavati
translated: Then it occurred to me:🔽When what exists does birth come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayā ca punar jātiḥ /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayā ca punar jātiḥ
translated: And with what as condition is birth?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽bhave sati jātir bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  bhave sati jātiḥ bhavati
translated: As I pondered this, my friends, the breakthrough came:🔽When there is existence, birth comes to be.

original: bhavapratyayā ca punar jātiḥ /
analyzed: bhava pratyayā ca punar jātiḥ
translated: And with existence as condition is birth.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati bhavo bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati bhavaḥ bhavati
translated: Then it occurred to me:🔽When what exists does existence come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayaś ca punar bhavaḥ /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayaḥ ca punar bhavaḥ
translated: And with what as condition is existence?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽upādāne sati bhavo bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  upādāne sati bhavaḥ bhavati
translated: As I pondered this, my friends, the breakthrough came:🔽When there is grasping, existence comes to be.

original: upādānapratyayaś ca punar bhavaḥ /
analyzed: upādāna pratyayaḥ ca punar bhavaḥ
translated: And with grasping as condition is existence.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: Then it occurred to me:

original: kasmin nu saty upādānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu sati upādānam bhavati
translated: When what exists does clinging come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayañ ca punar upādānam /🔽tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayam ca punar upādānam  tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: And with what as condition is clinging?🔽When I had reflected thoroughly with right wisdom,

original: tṛṣṇāyāṃ satyām upādānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tṛṣṇāyām satyām upādānam bhavati
translated: this appeared to me: When craving exists, clinging comes to be;

original: tṛṣṇāpratyayañ ca punar upādānam /
analyzed: tṛṣṇā pratyayam ca punar upādānam
translated: and with craving as condition, clinging.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati tṛṣṇā bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati tṛṣṇā bhavati
translated: It occurred to me:🔽When what exists does craving come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayā ca punas tṛṣṇā /🔽tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayā ca punar tṛṣṇā  tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: And with what as condition is craving?🔽When I had reflected thoroughly with right wisdom,

original: vedanāyāṃ satyāṃ tṛṣṇā bhavati /
analyzed: vedanāyām satyām tṛṣṇā bhavati
translated: this appeared to me: When feeling exists, craving comes to be;

original: vedanāpratyayā ca punas tṛṣṇā /
analyzed: vedanā pratyayā ca punar tṛṣṇā
translated: and with feeling as condition, craving.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: It occurred to me:

original: kasmin nu sati vedanā bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu sati vedanā bhavati
translated: When what exists does feeling come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayā ca punar vedanā /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayā ca punar vedanā
translated: And with what as condition is feeling?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly with right wisdom,

original: sparśe sati vedanā bhavati /
analyzed: sparśe sati vedanā bhavati
translated: this appeared to me: When contact exists, feeling comes to be;

original: sparśapratyayā ca punar vedanā /
analyzed: sparśa pratyayā ca punar vedanā
translated: and with contact as condition, feeling.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: It occurred to me:

original: kasmin nu sati sparśo bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu sati sparśaḥ bhavati
translated: When what exists does contact come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayaś ca punaḥ sparśaḥ /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayaḥ ca punar sparśaḥ
translated: With what as condition is there contact?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽ṣaḍāyatane sati sparśo bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  ṣaṣ āyatane sati sparśaḥ bhavati
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly on this with wisdom, I understood as it really is:🔽When there is the six sense spheres, contact comes to be.

original: ṣaḍāyatanapratyayaś ca punaḥ sparśaḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana pratyayaḥ ca punar sparśaḥ
translated: And with the six sense spheres as condition there is contact.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati ṣaḍāyatanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati ṣaṣ āyatanam bhavati
translated: This occurred to me:🔽When what exists does the six sense spheres come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayañ ca punaḥ ṣaḍāyatanam /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayam ca punar ṣaṣ āyatanam
translated: With what as condition are there the six sense spheres?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽nāmarūpe sati ṣaḍāyatanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  nāma rūpe sati ṣaṣ āyatanam bhavati
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly on this with wisdom, I understood as it really is:🔽When there is name-and-form, the six sense spheres come to be.

original: nāmarūpapratyayañ ca punaḥ ṣaḍāyatanam /
analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam ca punar ṣaṣ āyatanam
translated: And with name-and-form as condition there are the six sense spheres.

original: NidSa / / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati nāmarūpaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati nāma rūpam bhavati
translated: This occurred to me:🔽When what exists does name-and-form come to be?

original: kiṃpratyañ ca punar nāmarūpam /
analyzed: kiṃpratyam ca punar nāma rūpam
translated: With what as condition is there name-and-form?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽vijñāne sati nāmarūpaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  vijñāne sati nāma rūpam bhavati
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly on this with wisdom, I understood as it really is:🔽When there is consciousness, name-and-form comes to be.

original: vijñānapratyayañ ca punar nāmarūpam /
analyzed: vijñāna pratyayam ca punar nāma rūpam
translated: And with consciousness as condition there is name-and-form.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: NidSa 1.1. Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nu sati vijñānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu sati vijñānam bhavati
translated: “When what exists does consciousness come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayañ ca punar vijñānam /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayam ca punar vijñānam
translated: With what as condition is there consciousness?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽saṃskāreṣu satsu vijñānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  saṃskāreṣu satsu vijñānam bhavati
translated: Then, monks, as I was musing thus with insight, this occurred to me:🔽“When there are volitions, consciousness comes to be.

original: saṃskārapratyayañ ca punar vijñānam /
analyzed: saṃskāra pratyayam ca punar vijñānam
translated: With volitions as condition is consciousness.”

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /🔽kasmin nu sati saṃskārā bhavanti /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat  kasmin nu sati saṃskārāḥ bhavanti
translated: NidSa 1.2. Then this occurred to me:🔽“When what exists do volitions come to be?

original: kiṃpratyayāś ca punaḥ saṃskārāḥ /
analyzed: kiṃpratyayāḥ ca punar saṃskārāḥ
translated: With what as condition are there volitions?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽avidyāyāṃ satyāṃ saṃskārā bhavanti /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  avidyāyām satyām saṃskārāḥ bhavanti
translated: Then, monks, as I was musing thus with insight, this occurred to me:🔽“When there is ignorance, volitions come to be.

original: avidyāpratyayāś ca punaḥ saṃskārāḥ /
analyzed: avidyā pratyayāḥ ca punar saṃskārāḥ
translated: With ignorance as condition are volitions.”

original: NidSa / ity avidyāpratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ /
analyzed: iti avidyā pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ
translated: NidSa 1.3. Thus with ignorance as condition there are volitions.

original: saṃskārapratyayaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: saṃskāra pratyayam vijñānam
translated: With volitions as condition, consciousness.

original: vijñānapratyayaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam
translated: With consciousness as condition, name-and-form.

original: nāmarūpapratyayaṃ ṣaḍāyatanam /
analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam ṣaṣ āyatanam
translated: With name-and-form as condition, the six sense spheres.

original: ṣaḍāyatanapratyayaḥ sparśaḥ /🔽sparśapratyayā vedanā /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana pratyayaḥ sparśaḥ  sparśa pratyayā vedanā
translated: With the six sense spheres as condition, contact.🔽With contact as condition, feeling.

original: vedanāpratyayā tṛṣṇā /
analyzed: vedanā pratyayā tṛṣṇā
translated: With feeling as condition, craving.

original: tṛṣṇāpratyayam upādānam /
analyzed: tṛṣṇā pratyayam upādānam
translated: With craving as condition: attachment.

original: upādānapratyayo bhavaḥ /
analyzed: upādāna pratyayaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: With attachment as condition: continuation.

original: bhavapratyayā jatiḥ /
analyzed: bhava pratyayā jatiḥ
translated: With continuation as condition: birth.

original: jātipratyayaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: jāti pratyayam jarā maraṇam śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: With birth as condition: old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair (all) arise.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavati /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya samudayaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus there is an origination of this whole great mass of suffering.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: To me, monks, it occurred:

original: kasmin nv asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati jarā maraṇam na bhavati
translated: “When what does not exist does old age and death not occur?

original: kasya nirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of old age and death occur?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisanaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisanayaḥ udapādi
translated: To me, monks, while reflecting thus, this occurred:

original: jātyām asatyāṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: jātyām asatyām jarā maraṇam na bhavati
translated: “When there is no birth, old age and death do not occur.

original: jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of birth, the cessation of old age and death occurs.”

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: To me, monks, it occurred:

original: kasmin nv asati jātir na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati jātiḥ na bhavati
translated: “When what does not exist does birth not occur?

original: kasya nirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of birth occur?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽bhave 'sati jātir na bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  bhave sati jātiḥ na bhavati
translated: To me, monks, while reflecting thus, this occurred:🔽“When there is no continuation, birth does not occur.

original: bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of continuation, the cessation of birth occurs.”

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad ahavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat ahavat
translated: NidSa 1.1. Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati bhavo na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati bhavaḥ na bhavati
translated: “When what does not exist does becoming not exist?

original: kasya nirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt bhava nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of becoming come about?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvta evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvte evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, monks, when I had applied my mind to this, this occurred to me:

original: upādāne 'sati bhavo na bhavati /
analyzed: upādāne sati bhavaḥ na bhavati
translated: “When there is no attachment, becoming does not exist.

original: upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /
translated: With the cessation of attachment, the cessation of becoming comes about.”

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: NidSa 1.2. Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asaty upādānaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati upādānam na bhavati
translated: “When what does not exist does attachment not exist?

original: kasya nirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt upādāna nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of attachment come about?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamava udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamavaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, monks, when I had applied my mind to this, this occurred to me:

original: tṛṣṇāyām asatyām upādānaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: tṛṣṇāyām asatyām upādānam na bhavati
translated: “When there is no craving, attachment does not exist.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /
translated: With the cessation of craving, the cessation of attachment comes about.”

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: NidSa 1.3. Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati tṛṣṇā na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati tṛṣṇā na bhavati
translated: “When what does not exist does craving not exist?

original: kasya nirodhāt tṛṣṇānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt tṛṣṇā nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of craving come about?”

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /🔽vedanāyām asatyāṃ tṛṣṇā na bhavati /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi  vedanāyām asatyām tṛṣṇā na bhavati
translated: Then, monks, when I had applied my mind to this, this occurred to me:🔽“When there is no feeling, craving does not exist.

original: vedanānirodhāt ṭṣṇānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: vedanā nirodhāt ṭṣṇā nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of feeling, the cessation of craving comes about.”

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: This occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati vedanā na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati vedanā na bhavati
translated: When what does not exist does feeling not exist?

original: kasya nirodhād vedanānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of feeling occur?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly on this, the realization came to me as it really is:

original: sparśe 'sati vedanā na bhavati /
analyzed: sparśe sati vedanā na bhavati
translated: When contact does not exist, feeling does not exist.

original: sparśanirodhād vedanānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: sparśa nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of contact, the cessation of feeling occurs.🔽NidSa 1.2

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: This occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati sparśo na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati sparśaḥ na bhavati
translated: When what does not exist does contact not exist?

original: kasya nirodhāt sparśanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt sparśa nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what does the cessation of contact occur?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly on this, the realization came to me as it really is:

original: ṣaḍāyatane 'sati sparśo na bhavati /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatane sati sparśaḥ na bhavati
translated: When the six sense spheres do not exist, contact does not exist.

original: ṣaḍāyatananirodhāt sparśanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhāt sparśa nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of the six sense spheres, the cessation of contact occurs.🔽NidSa 1.3

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: This occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati ṣaḍāyatanaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati ṣaṣ āyatanam na bhavati
translated: When what does not exist do the six sense spheres not exist?

original: kasya nirodhāt ṣaḍāyatananirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of what do the six sense spheres cease?

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: When I had reflected thoroughly on this, the realization came to me as it really is:

original: nāmarūpe 'sati ṣaḍāyatanaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: nāma rūpe sati ṣaṣ āyatanam na bhavati
translated: When name-and-form does not exist, the six sense spheres do not exist.

original: nāmarūpanirodhāt ṣaḍāyatananirodhaḥ /
analyzed: nāma rūpa nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of name-and-form, the cessation of the six sense spheres.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati nāmarūpaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati nāma rūpam na bhavati
translated: ‘When what does not exist does name-and-form not exist?

original: kasya nirodhān nāmārūpanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt nāma a rūpa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of what does the cessation of name-and-form come about?’

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, monks, regarding these five components (of mind and body) that provide fuel for attachment, having seen the arising, the vanishing, the satisfaction, the danger, and the escape in this way through proper wisdom, I directly experienced the highest freedom of mind, the highest freedom through wisdom, being truly and properly a noble one with knowledge and conduct, a sage, a great seer.

original: vijñāne 'sati nāmarūpaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: vijñāne sati nāma rūpam na bhavati
translated: When consciousness does not exist, name-and-form does not exist.

original: vijñānanirodhān nāmarūpanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: vijñāna nirodhāt nāma rūpa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of consciousness, the cessation of name-and-form.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati vijñānaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati vijñānam na bhavati
translated: ‘When what does not exist does consciousness not exist?

original: kasya nirodhād vijñānanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt vijñāna nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of what does the cessation of consciousness come about?’

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, monks, regarding these five components (of mind and body) that provide fuel for attachment, having seen the arising, the vanishing, the satisfaction, the danger, and the escape in this way through proper wisdom, I directly experienced the highest freedom of mind, the highest freedom through wisdom, being truly and properly a noble one with knowledge and conduct, a sage, a great seer.

original: saṃskāreṣv asatsu vijñānaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: saṃskāreṣu asatsu vijñānam na bhavati
translated: When volitions do not exist, consciousness does not exist.

original: saṃskāranirodhād vijñānanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: saṃskāra nirodhāt vijñāna nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of volitions, the cessation of consciousness.

original: NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: Then this occurred to me:

original: kasmin nv asati saṃskārā na bhavanti /
analyzed: kasmin nu asati saṃskārāḥ na bhavanti
translated: ‘When what does not exist do volitions not exist?

original: kasya nirodhāt saṃskāranirodhaḥ /
analyzed: kasya nirodhāt saṃskāra nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of what do volitions cease?’

original: tasya mama yoniśo manasi kurvata evaṃ yathābhūtasyābhisamaya udapādi /
analyzed: tasya mama yoniśas manasi kurvataḥ evam yathābhūtasya abhisamayaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, monks, regarding these five components (of mind and body) that provide fuel for attachment, having seen the arising, the vanishing, the satisfaction, the danger, and the escape in this way through proper wisdom, I directly experienced the highest freedom of mind, the highest freedom through wisdom, being truly and properly a noble one with knowledge and conduct, a sage, a great seer.

original: avidyāyām asatyāṃ saṃskārā na bhavanti /🔽avidyānirodhāt saṃskāranirodhaḥ /
analyzed: avidyāyām asatyām saṃskārāḥ na bhavanti  avidyā nirodhāt saṃskāra nirodhaḥ
translated: When ignorance does not exist, volitional formations do not come to be.🔽From the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of volitional formations.

original: NidSa / ity avidyānirodhāt saṃskāranirodhaḥ /
analyzed: iti avidyā nirodhāt saṃskāra nirodhaḥ
translated: Thus, from the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of volitional formations.

original: saṃskāranirodhād vijñānanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: saṃskāra nirodhāt vijñāna nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of volitional formations comes the cessation of consciousness.

original: vijñānanirodhān nāmarūpanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: vijñāna nirodhāt nāma rūpa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of consciousness comes the cessation of name-and-form.

original: nāmarūpanirodhāt ṣaḍāyatananirodhaḥ /
analyzed: nāma rūpa nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of name-and-form comes the cessation of the six sense spheres.

original: ṣaḍāyatananirodhāt sparśanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhāt sparśa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of the six sense spheres comes the cessation of contact.

original: sparśanirodhād vedanānirodhaḥ /🔽vedanānirodhāt tṛṣṇānirodhaḥ /
analyzed: sparśa nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ  vedanā nirodhāt tṛṣṇā nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of contact comes the cessation of feeling.🔽From the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving.

original: tṛṣṇānirodhād upādānanirodhaḥ /🔽upādānanirodhād bhavanirodhaḥ /
translated: From the cessation of craving comes the cessation of clinging.🔽From the cessation of clinging comes the cessation of existence.

original: bhavanirodhāj jātinirodhaḥ /
analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of existence comes the cessation of birth.

original: jātinirodhāj jarāmaraṇanirodhaḥ /
analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of birth comes the cessation of old age and death.

original: śokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasopāyāsā nirudhyante /
analyzed: śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasa upāyāsāḥ nirudhyante
translated: Sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease.

original: evam asya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya nirodho bhavati /🔽NidSa / tasya mamaitad abhavat /
analyzed: evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati  tasya mama etat abhavat
translated: Thus ceases this whole great mass of suffering.🔽I thought:

original: adhigato me paurāṇo mārgaḥ paurāṇaṃ vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakair ṛṣibhir yātānuyātā /
analyzed: adhigataḥ me paurāṇaḥ mārgaḥ paurāṇam vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakaiḥ ṛṣibhiḥ yātā anuyātā
translated: The ancient path, the ancient route, the ancient trail traveled by the noble ones of the past has been discovered by me.

original: NidSa / tadyathā puruṣo 'raṇye pravaṇe 'nvāhiṇḍann adhigacchet paurāṇaṃ mārgaṃ paurāṇaṃ vartma paurāṇīṃ pūṭāṃ pūrvakair manuṣyair yātānuyātām
analyzed: tat yathā puruṣaḥ raṇye pravaṇe nu āhiṇḍan adhigacchet paurāṇam mārgam paurāṇam vartma paurāṇīm pūṭām pūrvakaiḥ manuṣyaiḥ yāta anuyātām
translated: NidSa 1.1.1.1. Just as if a man, wandering in the forest, in the wilderness, were to come upon an ancient path, an ancient road, travelled upon by people of former times,

original: sa tam anugacchet /
analyzed: sa tam anugacchet
translated: and he were to follow it,

original: sa tam anugacchan sa tatra paśyet paurāṇaṃ nagaraṃ paurāṇīṃ rājadhānīm ārāmasaṃpannāṃ vanasaṃpannāṃ puṣkariṇīsaṃpannāṃ śubhāṃ dāpavatīṃ ramaṇīyām
analyzed: sa tam anugacchan sa tatra paśyet paurāṇam nagaram paurāṇīm rājadhānīm ārāma saṃpannām vana saṃpannām puṣkariṇī saṃpannām śubhām dāpavatīm ramaṇīyām
translated: and as he followed it, he were to see an ancient city, an ancient capital, prosperous, populous, full of people, with good prospects, delightful,

original: NidSa / tasyaivaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tasya evam syāt
translated: NidSa 1.1.1.2. He would think:

original: yanv ahaṃ gatvā rājña ārocayeyam /
analyzed: yanu aham gatvā rājñe ārocayeyam
translated: 'Let me go and inform the king.'

original: atha sa puruṣo rājña evam ārocayet /
analyzed: atha sa puruṣaḥ rājñe evam ārocayet
translated: Then that man would inform the king thus:

original: yat khalu deva jānīyāḥ /
analyzed: yat khalu deva jānīyāḥ
translated: 'Your Majesty should know that

original: ihāham adrākṣam araṇye pravaṇe 'nvāhiṇḍan paurāṇaṃ mārgaṃ paurāṇaṃ vartma paurāṇīṃ puṭāṃ pūrvakair manuṣyair yātānuyātām /
analyzed: iha aham adrākṣam araṇye pravaṇe nu āhiṇḍan paurāṇam mārgam paurāṇam vartma paurāṇīm puṭām pūrvakaiḥ manuṣyaiḥ yāta anuyātām
translated: here I saw in the forest, in the wilderness, an ancient path, an ancient road, travelled upon by people of former times,

original: so 'haṃ tam anugatavān /
analyzed: saḥ ham tam anugatavān
translated: and I followed it,

original: so 'haṃ tam anugacchann adrākṣaṃ paurāṇaṃ nagaraṃ paurāṇīṃ rājadhānīṃ vanasaṃpannāṃ puṣkariṇīsaṃpannāṃ śubhāṃ dāpavatīṃ ramaṇīyām /🔽tāṃ devo nagarīṃ māpayatu /
analyzed: saḥ ham tam anugacchan adrākṣam paurāṇam nagaram paurāṇīm rājadhānīm vana saṃpannām puṣkariṇī saṃpannām śubhām dāpavatīm ramaṇīyām  tām devaḥ nagarīm māpayatu
translated: Following him, I saw an ancient city, an ancient royal capital, prosperous, full of people, crowded with people, with plenty of food, with many parks, ponds, and lotus pools, beautiful, delightful.🔽Let Your Majesty build a city there.

original: NidSa / atha sa rājā tāṃ nagarīṃ māpayet /
analyzed: atha sa rājā tām nagarīm māpayet
translated: Then the king would build that city.

original: sā syād apareṇa samayena rājadhānī ṛddhā ca sphītā ca kṣemā ca subhikṣā cākīrṇabahujanamanuṣyā ca /
analyzed: sā syāt apareṇa samayena rājadhānī ṛddhā ca sphītā ca kṣemā ca subhikṣā ca ākīrṇa bahu jana manuṣyā ca
translated: And after some time, that city would become a royal capital, prosperous, flourishing, secure, with plenty of food, crowded with people, and full of men and women.

original: NidSa / evam eva adhigato me paurāṇo mārgaḥ paurāṇaṃ vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakair ṛṣibhir yātānuyātā /
analyzed: evam eva adhigataḥ me paurāṇaḥ mārgaḥ paurāṇam vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakaiḥ ṛṣibhiḥ yātā anuyātā
translated: In the same way, I have discovered the ancient path, the ancient route, the ancient trail that seers of old have traveled and traversed.

original: NidSa / katamaś ca sa paurāṇo mārgaḥ paurāṇaṃ vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakair ṛṣibhir yātānuyātā /
analyzed: katamaḥ ca sa paurāṇaḥ mārgaḥ paurāṇam vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakaiḥ ṛṣibhiḥ yātānuyātā
translated: What is that ancient path, that ancient route, that ancient trail that seers of old have traveled and traversed?

original: NidSa / yad utāryāṣṭāṅgo mārgas tadyathā samyagdṛṣṭiḥ samyaksaṃkaIpaḥ samyagvāk samyakkarmāntaḥ samyagājīvaḥ samyagvyāyāmaḥ samyaksmṛtiḥ samyaksamādhiḥ /
analyzed: yat uta ārya aṣṭa aṅgaḥ mārgaḥ tat yathā samyak dṛṣṭiḥ samyak saṃkaipaḥ samyak vāc samyak karmāntaḥ samyak ājīvaḥ samyak vyāyāmaḥ samyak smṛtiḥ samyak samādhiḥ
translated: It is this: the noble eightfold path, namely right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.

original: NidSa / asau bhiksavaḥ paurāṇo mārgaḥ paurāṇaṃ vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakair ṛṣibhir yātānuyātā /
analyzed: asau bhiksavaḥ paurāṇaḥ mārgaḥ paurāṇam vartma paurāṇī puṭā pūrvakaiḥ ṛṣibhiḥ yātānuyātā
translated: NidSa 1.1.1: “Monks, that is the ancient path, the ancient road, the ancient way, which seers of old have traveled and traversed.

original: NidSa / tam aham anugatavān /
analyzed: nidsa tam aham anugatavān
translated: NidSa 1.1.2: “I have followed that.

original: tam anugacchañ jarāmaraṇaṃ adrākṣam /
analyzed: tam anugaccham jarā maraṇam adrākṣam
translated: Following that, I saw old age and death.

original: jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminīṃ pratipadam adrākṣam /
analyzed: jarā maraṇa samudayam jarā maraṇa nirodham jarā maraṇa nirodha gāminīm pratipadam adrākṣam
translated: I saw the arising of old age and death, the cessation of old age and death, and the path leading to the cessation of old age and death.

original: NidSa / evaṃ jātibhavopādānatṛṣṇāvedanāsparśaṣaḍāyatananāmarūpavijñānaṃ saṃskārān adrākṣam /
analyzed: evam jāti bhava upādāna tṛṣṇā vedanā sparśa ṣaṣ āyatana nāma rūpa vijñānam saṃskārān adrākṣam
translated: NidSa 1.1.3: “Thus I saw birth, existence, clinging, craving, feeling, contact, the six sense bases, name and form, consciousness, and volitional formations.

original: saṃskārasamudayaṃ saṃskāranirodhaṃ saṃskāranirodhagāminīṃ pratipadam adrākṣam /
analyzed: saṃskāra samudayam saṃskāra nirodham saṃskāra nirodha gāminīm pratipadam adrākṣam
translated: I saw the arising of volitional formations, the cessation of volitional formations, and the path leading to the cessation of volitional formations.

original: NidSa / so 'ham imān dharmān svayam abhijñāya sākṣīkṛtvā bhikṣūṇām ārocayāmi /
analyzed: nidsa saḥ ham imān dharmān svayam abhijñāya sākṣīkṛtvā bhikṣūṇām ārocayāmi
translated: NidSa 1.1.4: “Having directly known these things myself, I have declared them to the monks.

original: bhikṣūṇīnām upāsakānām upāsikānāṃ nānātīrthyaśramaṇabrāhmaṇacarakaparivrājakānām ārocayāmi /
analyzed: bhikṣūṇīnām upāsakānām upāsikānām nānā tīrthya śramaṇa brāhmaṇa caraka parivrājakānām ārocayāmi
translated: I have declared them to the nuns, male and female lay followers, and to various ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers of other sects.

original: NidSa / tatra bhikṣur api samyakpratipadyamāna ārādhiko bhavati /
analyzed: tatra bhikṣuḥ api samyak pratipadyamānaḥ ārādhikaḥ bhavati
translated: NidSa 1.1.5: “There, a monk who practices rightly becomes one who has attained,

original: ārādhayati nyāyaṃ dharmaṃ kuśalam /
analyzed: ārādhayati nyāyam dharmam kuśalam
translated: one who practices rightly attains the true Dhamma, the wholesome.”

original: bhikṣūṇy apy upāsako 'py upāsikāpi samyakpratipadyamānā ārādhikā bhavati /
analyzed: bhikṣūṇi api upāsakā upi upāsikā api samyak pratipadyamānā ārādhikā bhavati
translated: A nun, a lay follower, or a laywoman who practices well becomes one who has attained.

original: ārādhayati nyāyaṃ dharmaṃ kuśalam /
analyzed: ārādhayati nyāyam dharmam kuśalam
translated: One attains the right, wholesome Dhamma.

original: NidSa / evam idaṃ brahmacaryaṃ vaistārikaṃ bhavati bahujanyaṃ pṛthubhūtaṃ yāvad devamanuṣyebhyaḥ samyaksuprakāśitam //
analyzed: evam idam brahmacaryam vaistārikam bhavati bahu janyam pṛthu bhūtam yāvat deva manuṣyebhyaḥ samyak su prakāśitam
translated: Thus this spiritual life becomes widespread and popular, well-known, far-famed, and well-proclaimed among gods and humans.

original: Sūtra / naḍakalāpika Rohrbundel
analyzed: sūtra
translated: Sutra: A bundle of reeds, a bundle of bamboos

original: NidSa / bhagavān rājagṛhe viharati veṇuvane kalandakanivāpe /
analyzed: bhagavān rājagṛhe viharati veṇuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: Niddesa: The Blessed One was dwelling at Rajagaha in the Bamboo Grove at the Squirrel's Feeding Ground.

original: NidSa / tena khalu samayenāyuṣmāñ chāriputra āyuṣmāṃś ca mahākoṣṭhilo rājagṛhe viharato gṛdhrakūṭe parvate /
analyzed: tena khalu samayena āyuṣmān śāriputraḥ āyuṣmān ca mahākoṣṭhilaḥ rājagṛhe viharataḥ gṛdhrakūṭe parvate
translated: Niddesa: At that time, the Venerable Sariputta and the Venerable Mahakothili were dwelling at Rajagaha on the Vulture Peak mountain.

original: NidSa / / athāyuṣmāñ chāriputraḥ sāyāhne pratisaṃlayanād vyutthāya yenāyuṣmān mahākoṣṭhilas tenopajagāma /
analyzed: atha āyuṣmān śāriputraḥ sāyāhne pratisaṃlayanāt vyutthāya yena āyuṣmān mahākoṣṭhilaḥ tena upajagāma
translated: Niddesa: Then, in the evening, the Venerable Sariputta emerged from seclusion and approached the Venerable Mahakothili.

original: upetyāyuṣmatā mahākoṣṭhilena sārdhaṃ saṃmukhaṃ sammodanīṃ saṃrañjanīṃ kathāṃ vividhām upasaṃhṛtyaikānte nyaṣīdat /
analyzed: upetya āyuṣmatā mahākoṣṭhilena sārdham saṃmukham sammodanīm saṃrañjanīm kathām vividhām upasaṃhṛtya ekānte nyaṣīdat
translated: Having approached, he exchanged greetings with the Venerable Mahakothili, and after exchanging courteous and friendly greetings, he sat down to one side.

original: ekāntaniṣaṇṇa āyuṣmāñ chāriputra āyuṣmantaṃ mahākoṣṭhilam idam avocat /
analyzed: ekānta niṣaṇṇaḥ āyuṣmān śāriputraḥ āyuṣmantam mahākoṣṭhilam idam avocat
translated: The venerable Śāriputra, seated at one side, said this to the venerable Mahākoṣṭhila:

original: NidSa / pṛcchāma āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila kañcid eva pradeśam /
analyzed: nidsa pṛcchāmaḥ āyuṣmat mahākoṣṭhila kañcid eva pradeśam
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, I ask about a certain point,

original: saced avakāśaṃ kuryāḥ praśnasya vyākaraṇāya /
analyzed: saced avakāśam kuryāḥ praśnasya vyākaraṇāya
translated: if you would give me an opportunity to ask my question and to receive an answer.

original: NidSa / pṛcchāyuṣmañ chāriputra /
analyzed: nidsa pṛccha āyuṣman śāriputra
translated: Ask, venerable Śāriputra,

original: śrutvā te vedayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: śrutvā te vedayiṣyāmi
translated: having heard, I will know.

original: NidSa / kin nv āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila asti jarā /
analyzed: nidsa kim nu āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila asti jarā
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, is there old age?

original: asty evāyuṣmañ chāriputra jarā /
analyzed: asti eva āyuṣman śāriputra jarā
translated: Venerable Śāriputra, old age certainly exists.

original: NidSa / kin nv āyuṣman mahākoṣthila asti maraṇam /
analyzed: nidsa kim nu āyuṣmat mahākoṣthila asti maraṇam
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, is there death?

original: asty evāyuṣmañ chāriputra maraṇam /
analyzed: asti eva āyuṣman śāriputra maraṇam
translated: Venerable Śāriputra, death certainly exists.

original: NidSa / kin nv āyuṣmān mahākoṣṭhila svayaṃkṛtaṃ jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: nidsa kim nu āyuṣmān mahākoṣṭhila svayaṃkṛtam jarā maraṇam
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, is old age and death self-made?

original: aho svit parakṛtam /
analyzed: aho svid parakṛtam
translated: Or is it made by another?

original: aho svit svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: aho svid svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: Or is it made by both self and another?

original: aho svid asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: aho svid a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam jarā maraṇam
translated: Or does old age and death arise without a cause, being made neither by self nor by another?

original: na hy evāyuṣmañ chāriputra svayaṃkṛtaṃ jarāmaraṇam /🔽na parakṛtaṃ /
analyzed: na hi eva āyuṣman śāriputra svayaṃkṛtam jarā maraṇam  na para kṛtam
translated: Venerable Śāriputra, old age and death are not self-made.🔽They are not made by another.

original: na svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: na svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: They are not made by both self and another.

original: nāpy asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: na api a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam jarā maraṇam
translated: Nor is old age and death arisen from a cause that is self-made or made by another.

original: api tu jātipratyayaṃ jarāmaraṇam /
analyzed: api tu jāti pratyayam jarā maraṇam
translated: But rather, old age and death have birth as a condition.

original: NidSa / evaṃ jātir bhava upādānaṃ tṛṣṇā vedanā sparśaḥ ṣaḍāyatanaṃ nāmarūpaṃ vācyam /
analyzed: evam jātiḥ bhavaḥ upādānam tṛṣṇā vedanā sparśaḥ ṣaṣ āyatanam nāma rūpam vācyam
translated: In the same way, birth, existence, clinging, craving, feeling, contact, the six sense spheres, name-and-form should be explained.

original: NidSa / kin nv āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila svayaṃkṛtaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: nidsa kim nu āyuṣmat mahākoṣṭhila svayaṃkṛtam nāma rūpam
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, is name-and-form self-made?

original: aho svit parakṛtaṃ /
analyzed: aho svid parakṛtam
translated: Or is it made by another?

original: aho svit svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: aho svid svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: Or is it self-made and made by another?

original: aho svid asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: aho svid a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam nāma rūpam
translated: Or is name-and-form arisen from a cause that is neither self-made nor made by another?

original: na hy evāyuṣmañ chāripurta svayaṃkṛtaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: na hi eva āyuṣman śāripurta svayaṃkṛtam nāma rūpam
translated: Venerable Śāriputra, name-and-form is not self-made.

original: na parakṛtaṃ /
analyzed: na para kṛtam
translated: It is not made by another.

original: na svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: na svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: It is not self-made and made by another.

original: nāpy asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: na api a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam nāma rūpam
translated: Nor is name-and-form arisen from a cause that is neither self-made nor made by another.

original: api tu vijñānapratyayaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: api tu vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam
translated: But rather, name-and-form has consciousness as a condition.

original: NidSa / kin nv āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila svayaṃkṛtaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: nidsa kim nu āyuṣmat mahākoṣṭhila svayaṃkṛtam vijñānam
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, is consciousness self-made?

original: aho svit parakṛtam /
analyzed: aho svid parakṛtam
translated: Or is it made by another?

original: aho svit svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: aho svid svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: Or is it self-made and made by another?

original: aho svid asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: aho svid a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam vijñānam
translated: Or is consciousness arisen from a cause that is neither self-made nor made by another?

original: na hy evāyuṣmañ chāriputra svayaṃkṛtaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: na hi eva āyuṣman śāriputra svayaṃkṛtam vijñānam
translated: Venerable Śāriputra, consciousness is not produced by itself.

original: na parakṛtaṃ /
analyzed: na para kṛtam
translated: It is not produced by another.🔽It is not produced by both itself and another.

original: na svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: na svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: It is not produced by its own action.🔽It is not produced by the power of God.🔽It is not produced by chance.🔽It is not produced by the transformation of what was not.

original: nāpy asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: na api a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam vijñānam
translated: It is not produced by the combination of causes and conditions.

original: api tu nāmarūpapratyayaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: api tu nāma rūpa pratyayam vijñānam
translated: Rather, consciousness has name-and-form as its condition.

original: NidSa / idānīm evaṃ vayam āyuṣmato mahākoṣthilasya bhāṣitasyārtham ājānīmaḥ /
analyzed: idānīm evam vayam āyuṣmataḥ mahākoṣthilasya bhāṣitasya artham ājānīmaḥ
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, we now understand the meaning of what you have said as follows:

original: na svayaṃkṛtaṃ nāmarūpaṃ /
analyzed: na svayaṃkṛtam nāma rūpam
translated: Name-and-form is not produced by itself.

original: na parakṛtaṃ /
analyzed: na para kṛtam
translated: It is not produced by another.

original: na svayaṃkṛtañ ca parakṛtañ ca /
analyzed: na svayaṃkṛtam ca parakṛtam ca
translated: It is not produced by both itself and another.🔽Name-and-form is not produced by its own action.🔽It is not produced by the power of God.🔽It is not produced by chance.🔽It is not produced by the transformation of what was not.

original: nāpy asvayaṃkāraparakārahetusamutpannaṃ nāmarūpam /🔽api tu vijñānapratyayaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: na api a svayaṃkāra parakāra hetu samutpannam nāma rūpam  api tu vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam
translated: It is not produced by the combination of causes and conditions.🔽Rather, name-and-form has consciousness as its condition.

original: idānīṃ ca punar nāmarūpapratyayaṃ vijñānam ity ājānīmaḥ /
analyzed: idānīm ca punar nāma rūpa pratyayam vijñānam iti ājānīmaḥ
translated: And now we understand that consciousness has name-and-form as its condition.

original: ko nv āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila asya bhāṣitasyārtho draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ nu āyuṣmat mahākoṣṭhila asya bhāṣitasya arthaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, what is the meaning of this statement that should be seen?

original: NidSa / tenāsyāyuṣmañ chāriputra upamāṃ te kariṣyāmi /
analyzed: tena asya āyuṣman śāriputra upamām te kariṣyāmi
translated: Venerable Śāriputra, I will give you a simile.

original: upamayā hy atraikatyā vjñapuruṣā bhāṣitasyārtham ājānanti /
analyzed: upamayā hi atra ekatyāḥ v jña puruṣāḥ bhāṣitasya artham ājānanti
translated: For some wise people understand the meaning of a statement through a simile.

original: NidSa / tadyathā dvau naḍakalāpāv ākāśe ucchṛtau syātām anyonyaṃ niśṛtau /
analyzed: tat yathā dvau naḍa kalāpau ākāśe ucchṛtau syātām anyonyam niśṛtau
translated: NidSa 1.1.1. It is just as if two bundles of reeds were to stand leaning against each other.

original: a / / / / / / etāv anyonyaṃ niśṛtya tiṣṭhataḥ /🔽yaduta vijñānapratyayaṃ nāmarūpam /
analyzed: a etau anyonyam niśṛtya tiṣṭhataḥ  yat uta vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam
translated: They stand leaning on each other,🔽namely, consciousness with name-and-form as condition,

original: nāmarūpapratyayaṃ vijñānam /
analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam vijñānam
translated: and name-and-form with consciousness as condition.

original: NidSa / sādhu sādhv āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila yathā śrutavatāryaśrāvakeṇa samyag eva
analyzed: sādhu sādhu āyuṣmat mahākoṣṭhila yathā śrutavatā ārya śrāvakeṇa samyak eva
translated: NidSa 1.1.2. Very good, venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, just as a disciple who has learned well, who has understood the Teacher's Dispensation well,

original: śāstuḥ śāsanam ājānatā suvinītena viśāradenāmṛtadṛśā amṛtaṃ dhātuṃ kāyena sākṣīkṛtvopasaṃpadya
analyzed: śāstuḥ śāsanam ājānatā su vinītena viśāradena amṛta dṛśā amṛtam dhātum kāyena sākṣīkṛtvā upasaṃpadya
translated: who is well-trained, fearless, with eyes of knowledge, having realized with his body the deathless element, and is living in it,

original: viharatāyuṣmatā mahākoṣṭhilena imā evaṃrūpā gaṃbhīrā gaṃbhīrā praśnā vimṛśya vimṛśya
analyzed: viharatā āyuṣmatā mahākoṣṭhilena imāḥ evaṃrūpāḥ gaṃbhīrāḥ gaṃbhīrāḥ praśnāḥ vimṛśya vimṛśya
translated: the venerable Mahākoṣṭhila has answered these questions of such a profound nature, having considered them well,

original: samyakprajñayā pṛṣṭena vyākṛtāḥ /
analyzed: samyak prajñayā pṛṣṭena vyākṛtāḥ
translated: having been asked with right wisdom.

original: NidSa / cailoṇḍukam ivāyuṣmantaṃ mahākoṣṭhilaṃ ye sabrahmacāriṇo mūrdhnā pariharanta
analyzed: cailoṇḍukam iva āyuṣmantam mahākoṣṭhilam ye sabrahmacāriṇaḥ mūrdhnā pariharanta
translated: NidSa 1.1.3. Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, those fellow practitioners who would hold you on their heads

original: āyuṣmato mahākoṣṭhilasya labherañ ca darśanaṃ labherañ ca paryupāsanaṃ teṣāṃ syur lābhāḥ sulabdhāḥ /
analyzed: āyuṣmataḥ mahākoṣṭhilasya labheram ca darśanam labheram ca paryupāsanam teṣām syuḥ lābhāḥ su labdhāḥ
translated: and would obtain the opportunity to see and attend on the venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, for them it would be a great gain, well-gained.

original: asmākam api lābhāḥ sulabdhā ye vayam āyuṣmato mahākoṣṭhilasya labhāmahe ca darśanaṃ labhāmahe ca paryupāsanam /
analyzed: asmākam api lābhāḥ su labdhāḥ ye vayam āyuṣmataḥ mahākoṣṭhilasya labhāmahe ca darśanam labhāmahe ca paryupāsanam
translated: We too have gained great gain, in that we get to see the Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila and get to serve him.

original: NidSa / sādhv atrāyuṣmatā mahākoṣṭhilena dharmaparyāyo deśitaḥ /
analyzed: sādhu atra āyuṣmatā mahākoṣṭhilena dharmaparyāyaḥ deśitaḥ
translated: It is good that the Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila has taught this Dharma discourse here.

original: imam aham utsahāmi triṃśat / / / / / / / /
analyzed: imam aham utsahāmi triṃśat
translated: I am able to answer thirty...

original: NidSa / jarāmaraṇasya āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila bhikṣur nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya dharmaṃ deśayati dharmakathiko bhikṣur alam asya vacanāya /
analyzed: jarā maraṇasya āyuṣman mahākoṣṭhila bhikṣuḥ nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya dharmam deśayati dharma kathikaḥ bhikṣuḥ alam asya vacanāya
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, a monk who teaches the Dharma for the purpose of disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, and tranquility regarding old age and death is a Dharma teacher, and his words are worthy of acceptance.

original: jātibhavopādānatṛṣṇāvedanāsparśaṣaḍāyatananāmarūpavijñānasya bhikṣur nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya dharmaṃ deśayati dharmakathiko bhikṣur alam asya vacanāya /
analyzed: jāti bhava upādāna tṛṣṇā vedanā sparśa ṣaṣ āyatana nāma rūpa vijñānasya bhikṣuḥ nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya dharmam deśayati dharma kathikaḥ bhikṣuḥ alam asya vacanāya
translated: A monk who teaches the Dharma for the purpose of disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, and tranquility regarding birth, existence, clinging, craving, feeling, contact, the six sense bases, name and form, and consciousness is a Dharma teacher, and his words are worthy of acceptance.

original: NidSa / jarāmaraṇasya bhikṣur nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya pratipanno bhavati dharmakathiko bhikṣur alam asya vacanāya /
analyzed: jarā maraṇasya bhikṣuḥ nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya pratipannaḥ bhavati dharma kathikaḥ bhikṣuḥ alam asya vacanāya
translated: Venerable Mahākoṣṭhila, a monk who practices for the purpose of disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, and tranquility regarding old age and death is a Dharma teacher, and his words are worthy of acceptance.

original: yāvad vijñānasya bhikṣur nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya pratipanno bhavati dharmakathiko bhikṣur alam asya vacanāya /🔽NidSa / jarāmaraṇasya bhikṣur nirvide virāgāya nirodhāyānupādāyāsravebhyaḥ samyaksuvimuktacitto bhavati dharmakathiko bhikṣur alam asya vacanāya
analyzed: yāvat vijñānasya bhikṣuḥ nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya pratipannaḥ bhavati dharma kathikaḥ bhikṣuḥ alam asya vacanāya  jarā maraṇasya bhikṣuḥ nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya an upādāya āsravebhyaḥ samyak su vimukta cittaḥ bhavati dharma kathikaḥ bhikṣuḥ alam asya vacanāya
translated: A monk who has entered the path for the sake of dispassion, cessation, and relinquishing regarding consciousness is a monk who speaks Dharma.🔽A monk who is completely liberated in mind through dispassion, cessation, and relinquishing regarding old age and death without clinging to the influxes is a monk who speaks Dharma.

original: yāvad vijñānasya bikṣur nirvide virāgāya nirodhāyānupādāyāsravebyaḥ samyaksuvimuktacitto bhavati dharmakathiko bhikṣur alam asya vacanāya /
analyzed: yāvat vijñānasya bikṣuḥ nirvide virāgāya nirodhāya an upādāya āsravebyaḥ samyak su vimukta cittaḥ bhavati dharma kathikaḥ bhikṣuḥ alam asya vacanāya
translated: A monk who is completely liberated in mind through dispassion, cessation, and relinquishing regarding consciousness without clinging to the influxes is a monk who speaks Dharma.

original: NidSa / sādhu sādhv āyuṣmañ chāriputra yathā śrutavatāryaśrāvakeṇa samyag eva śāstuḥ śāsanam ājānatā suvinītena viśāradenāmṛtadṛśā
analyzed: sādhu sādhu āyuṣman śāriputra yathā śrutavatā ārya śrāvakeṇa samyak eva śāstuḥ śāsanam ājānatā su vinītena viśāradena amṛta dṛśā
translated: Excellent, venerable Śāriputra! As a disciple who has heard much, who has properly understood the Teacher's Dispensation, who is well-trained, confident, and has seen the state of peace,
